info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 6.

(1, 1).clue: Under Jean Chretien, in 2001 this country became the first to legalize marijuana for medical use

(2, 1).clue: He ran an historic 5,280 feet on May 6, 1954, later became a neurologist & was knighted in 1975

(3, 1).clue: This movie "Daredevil" is lucky at cards: he won the 2004 California State Poker Championship

(4, 1).clue: Covering 2% of the Earth's surface, they're disappearing at the rate of several acres a minute

(5, 1).clue: The power went out on this Houston company when it declared bankruptcy in December 2001

(6, 1).clue: In the '70s Jon Landau wrote he saw rock & roll's future & its name was this Jersey guy; guess he was right

(1, 2).clue: 9-letter term for a body part, like the sinoatrial node, that is a regulator of bodily rhythm

(2, 2).clue: GM's chairman from 1981 to 1990, he was the Roger in the documentary "Roger & Me"

(3, 2).clue: "Ready. Aim. Scream" is the slogan of this Buena Park theme park's Silver Bullet ride

(5, 2).clue: This airline's "Friendly Skies" were darkened by its Dec. 2002 bankruptcy

(6, 2).clue: 1930's "Anna Christie" was advertised with the line "Garbo" does this

(1, 3).clue: "The Hot Zone", a medical thriller, tells the true story of an outbreak of this virus near Washington, D.C.

(2, 3).clue: In 1996, he became the founding chairman & CEO of Fox News

(3, 3).clue: Huzzah!  The Old Globe Theatre in this city's Balboa Park is celebrating its 70th anniversary in 2005

(4, 3).clue: Onesies are a standard gift at this type of event

(5, 3).clue: In Jan. 2002 this undersea fiber optic telecom co. founded by Gary Winnick sank beneath the bankruptcy waves

(6, 3).clue: Opening at No. 1 at the box office in 2004, a prequel to this 1973 horror flick really "turned some heads"

(1, 4).clue: Factor VIII is a protein in the blood that helps it do this

(2, 4).clue: The New England university named for this man is seen here

(3, 4).clue: At L.A.'s George C. Page Museum, watch scientists clean & identify specimens plucked from this primeval pool next door

(4, 4).clue: In 2001 a S.F. Chronicle writer defended Pres. Bush's vacation by pointing out that W. has this type of job

(5, 4).clue: $11 billion in alleged fraud might've played a tiny part in this long-distance co.'s July 2002 bankruptcy

(6, 4).clue: Imitation gruel & "Non-Toxic Kologne" are endorsed by this "Simpsons" "k"lown

(1, 5).clue: The name of these pain suppressors is short for endogenous morphines

(2, 5).clue: This 6-time Hugo-winning sci-fi writer's last name was near the end of the phone book

(3, 5).clue: This town in the Santa Ynez valley is "The Danish capital of America", so, yes, you'll find lots of pastry there

(4, 5).clue: To have another city as one's birthplace or residence

(5, 5).clue: Conspiracy & fraud led to a June 2002 "reorganization" of this cable co. led by the Rigas family

(6, 5).clue: In 1992 Rene Echevarria wrote the classic "I, Borg" episode of this Patrick Stewart series

(1, 1).clue: The novel "Moby-Dick" calls this decorative art "skrimshander"

(3, 1).clue: This measure of booze equals .666 jigger or 1 ounce

(4, 1).clue: Born in 1906, Samuel Beckett attended Trinity College in this city

(5, 1).clue: Not surprisingly, in Korean this city's name means "capital city"

(6, 1).clue: Your body's metabolism is regulated by hormones from this gland

(1, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew spins a clay pot on a wheel in Greece.)  Keramos, a Greek word for "clay", gave us this English word for pottery

(3, 2).clue: As I understand it, this unit used to measure the depth of water equals 6 feet

(4, 2).clue: Beckett won this big prize in 1969, but declined the trip to Sweden to avoid the public speeches at the ceremony

(5, 2).clue: In 1831 the city of Thang Long changed its name to this, a capital idea by the Vietnamese

(6, 2).clue: After meeting the basic requirements for scout, a Boy Scout achieves this rank

(1, 3).clue: This ornamental covering on the back of an upholstered couch was meant to protect against a specific hair oil

(3, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from JFK Airport in New York.)  Each of these bricks of cocaine, seized by Homeland Security agents, weighs this metric unit & has a street value of over $15,000

(4, 3).clue: It's the English title of the play Beckett originally worte in French as "Fin de partie"

(5, 3).clue: In exile, Lenin ran a training school for Russian revolutionists at Longjumeau, a suburb of this capital city

(6, 3).clue: This word for a device popularized in the 1800s can mean to signal your plans unintentionally

(1, 4).clue: From the French for partition, it's enamel work in which colored areas are separated by thin metal bands

(3, 4).clue: The weight system used for gems & precious metals; 1.215 of its pounds equals one avoirdupois pound

(4, 4).clue: Beckett is a major dramatist of the "Theater of" this, which portrays a bewildered & anxious humanity

(5, 4).clue: Razed in the 16th century, the reconstructed ruins of Templo Mayor are found in this capital's Zocalo

(6, 4).clue: This lover of Cressida was killed by Achilles

(1, 5).clue: This iridescent substance used as an inlay on the lacquered box seen here is also called mother-of-pearl

(3, 5).clue: The name of this unit of force comes from the Greek for "force" or "power"

(4, 5).clue: It's subtitled "A Tragicomedy in Two Acts"

(5, 5).clue: Honoring one of the country's famous sons, the Universidad de Belgrano is found in this South American capital

(6, 5).clue: It's the "bewitching" first name of Stephen King's wife; she's an author, too

(0, 0).clue: This real man inspired a 1719 novel character & a poem that says, "I am monarch of all I survey"
